item.title: course1
item.description:
Build a foundation in Python.(è¿™é‡Œæ˜¯è¯¾ç¨‹çš„æ¦‚è¿°ï¼Œå…·ä½“å†…å®¹æˆ–è€…ä½œå“å±•ç¤ºæ”¾åœ¨è¯¥ç½‘é¡µé‡Œ)

1-2 hours per week, for 8 weeks

Learn

Quiz

What is the difference between lists and tuples?

Lists

  • Lists are mutable - they can be changed
  • Slower than tuples
  • Syntax: a_list = [1, 2.0, 'Hello world']

Tuples

  • Tuples are immutable - they can’t be changed
  • Tuples are faster than lists
  • Syntax: a_tuple = (1, 2.0, 'Hello world')

Is Python case-sensitive?

Yes

ç§»è½´æ‘„å½±ä¼šæ‹å‡ºå°äººå›½çš„æ•ˆæœçš„åŸå› ï¼šåœ¨æ­£å¸¸æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œæ™¯æ·±åŒå¯¹ç„¦ç‚¹è·ç¦»æˆæ­£æ¯”ï¼ŒåŒé•œå¤´ç„¦è·é•¿åº¦æˆåæ¯”ï¼Œäººçœ¼ä¹Ÿç¬¦åˆè¿™ä¸ªè§„å¾‹ï¼Œå¤§è„‘åœ¨é•¿æœŸçš„è®­ç»ƒä¸‹ä¹Ÿé»˜è®¤äº†è¿™ä¸ªè§„åˆ™ã€‚ç§»è½´é•œå¤´å¯ä»¥æ”¹å˜å…‰è·¯ï¼Œä½¿å¾—ç„¦å¹³é¢å’Œæ„Ÿå…‰å¹³é¢ä¸å¹³è¡Œï¼Œåªæœ‰ä¸¤ä¸ªå¹³é¢ç›¸äº¤çš„é‚£æ¡çº¿é™„è¿‘çš„æ™¯ç‰©æ¸…æ™°ï¼Œé€ æˆç‰¹æ®Šçš„â€œæµ…æ™¯æ·±â€ã€‚é‚£ç§çœ‹èµ·æ¥åƒæ¨¡å‹çš„ç§»è½´ç…§ç‰‡å¤šæ˜¯å¹¿è§’è¿œè·ç¦»æ‹æ‘„ï¼Œåœ¨å¤§è„‘çš„è§„åˆ™ä¸­ï¼Œè¿™ç§è·ç¦»çš„å¹¿è§’è§†è§’ä¸‹ä¸å¯èƒ½å‡ºç°æµ…æ™¯æ·±ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä¼šäº§ç”Ÿé”™è§‰ï¼Œä»¥ä¸ºè¿™æ˜¯è¿‘è·ç¦»æ‘„å½±ã€‚åœ¨è¿‘è·ç¦»æ™¯ç‰©åˆæ¯”è¾ƒå°çš„è¯ï¼Œå°±åƒæ˜¯æ¨¡å‹äº†ã€‚

è§†é¢‘è½¬è½½äºæ— é™é£“é£

Code

Wowchemy supports a Markdown extension for highlighting code syntax. You can enable this feature by toggling the syntax_highlighter option in your config/_default/params.toml file.

```python
import pandas as pd
data = pd.read_csv("data.csv")
data.head()
```

renders as

import pandas as pd
data = pd.read_csv("data.csv")
data.head()

Charts

Save your Plotly JSON in your page folder, for example line-chart.json, and then add the {{< chart data="line-chart" >}} shortcode where you would like the chart to appear.

Demo:

You might also find the Plotly JSON Editor useful.

Diagrams

An example flowchart:

```mermaid
graph TD
A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round)
B --> C{Decision}
C -->|One| D[Result 1]
C -->|Two| E[Result 2]
```

renders as

graph TD A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round) B --> C{Decision} C -->|One| D[Result 1] C -->|Two| E[Result 2]

Tables

Save your spreadsheet as a CSV file in your page’s folder and then render it by adding the Table shortcode to your page:

{{< table path="results.csv" header="true" caption="Table 1: My results" >}}

renders as

customer_id score
1 0
2 0.5
3 1
Table 1: My results

item.title: In search of an ending
item.description:
Foreign private-equity barons circle a fading jewel of corporate Japan

Toshiba was once synonymous with Japanâ€™s industrial might. Of late the conglomerate, which has made everything from memory cards to nuclear reactors, has become a byword for drama. Japanâ€™s business press writes ofâ€œToshiba Theatreâ€, which began with accounting fraud a decade ago and has continued to the present day in a series of â€œslapstickâ€ struggles between management and shareholders. Toshibaâ€™s share price has underperformed domestic and foreign rivals, as well as the broaderJapanese stockmarket (see chart).The latest plot twist comes amid talk of a buyÂ­out led by Bain Capital, an American privateÂ­equity group. This raised hopes among investors for some sort of resolution to the saga. Toshibaâ€™s market value has risen by a quarterin the past month.

item.title: Seeing and believing
item.description:
Tech firms are betting that â€œextended realityâ€ glasses could be the next big productâ€”and perhaps the next big platform

With eyes like saucers, nine-year-old Ralph Miles slowly removes his Quest 2 headset. â€œIt was like being in another galaxy!â€ he exclaims. He has just spent ten minutes blasting alien robotswith deafening laser cannonsâ€”all the while seated silently in the home-electronics section of a London department store.Sales assistants bustle around, advertising the gear to take home today. â€œThat would be sick!â€ enthuses Ralph. â€œDonâ€™t get him started,â€ warns his dad.

Children are no longer the only ones excited about â€œextended realityâ€, a category which includes both fully immersive virtual reality (vr) and augmented reality (ar), in which computer imagery is superimposed onto usersâ€™ view of the world around them. Nearly every big technology firm is rushing to develop a vr or ar headset, convinced that what has long been a niche market may be on the brink of becoming something much larger.
